revision.text:
{{Otherships|HMS Express}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:Express plans.png|300px]] |Ship caption=Laird plans for ''Express'' }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag= {{shipboxflag|United Kingdom|naval}} |Ship name=HMS ''Express'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder= [[Cammell Laird|Laird, Son & Co.]], [[Birkenhead]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=1 December 1896 |Ship launched=11 December 1897 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed=February 1902 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=[[ship breaking|Scrapped]], 1921 |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=[[Torpedo boat destroyer]] |Ship displacement={{convert|465|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} |Ship length={{convert|239.25|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|23.5|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|10.25|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=*[[Marine steam engine#Triple or multiple expansion|vertical triple-expansion steam engines]] *Coal-fired [[Normand boiler]]s *{{convert|9250|hp|0|abbr=on}} |Ship speed= {{convert|31|kn|lk=in}} |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship complement=74 |Ship armament= *1 × [[QF 12 pounder 12 cwt naval gun|QF 12-pounder (76 mm) gun]] *2 × [[British 18 inch torpedo|18-inch (450 mm) torpedo]] tubes |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMS ''Express''''' was a [[B class destroyer (1913)|B-class]] [[torpedo boat destroyer]] of the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Royal Navy]]. She was completed by [[Cammell Laird|Laird, Son & Company]], [[Birkenhead]], in 1896. Like many contemporary British destroyers, she was a "builder's special", designed to Admiralty specifications but built to the builder's own design.
==Design and construction== The 1896–1897 shipbuilding programme of the British [[Admiralty]] included orders for 20 torpedo boat destroyers. Of these, 17 were "thirty-knotters", as ordered under the 1894–1895 and 1895–1896 programmes, which had a contract speed of {{convert|30|kn}}. The remaining three destroyers, ordered from [[Cammell Laird|Laird]] (''Express''), [[John Brown & Company|J & G Thomson]] ({{HMS|Arab|1901|2}}) and [[John I. Thornycroft & Company|Thornycroft]] ({{HMS|Albatross|1898|2}}) were "specials", which were required to reach higher speeds. While Thomson's and Thornycroft's destroyers had contract speeds of {{convert|32|kn}}, Laird's design was required to reach a speed of {{convert|33|kn}}.<ref name="Fried p53,5">Friedman 2009, pp. 53, 55.</ref><ref name="Lyon p23">Lyon 2001, p. 23.</ref>
''Express'' was {{convert|239|ft|6|in|m}} [[overall length|long overall]], with a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|23|ft|6|in}} and a [[Draft (ship)|draught]] of {{convert|14|ft|8|in|m}}. [[Displacement (ship)|Displacement]] was {{convert|465|LT|t}} light and {{convert|540|LT|t}} full load. Four coal-fired [[Normand boiler]]s fed steam at {{convert|240|psi}} to two [[Marine_steam_engine#Triple or multiple expansion|triple expansion engines]] rated at {{convert|9250|ihp|kW}}.<ref name="Lyon p26">Lyon 2001, p. 26.</ref> Four evenly spaced funnels were fitted.<ref name="Fried p55">Friedman 2009, p. 55.</ref> Up to {{convert|140|LT|t}} of coal were carried, sufficient to give an endurance of {{convert|1470|nmi}} at {{convert|11|kn}}.<ref name="Fried p292">Friedman 2009, p. 292.</ref>
''Express'' carried the specified armament for the thirty-knotters of a [[QF 12 pounder 12 cwt naval gun|QF 12 pounder 12 cwt]] ({{convert|3|in|mm|abbr=on}} calibre) gun on a platform on the ship's [[conning tower]] (in practice the platform was also used as the ship's bridge), with a secondary armament of five 6-pounder guns, and two 18-inch (450 mm) torpedo tubes.<ref name="Lyon p98-9">Lyon 2001, pp. 98–99.</ref><ref name="Fried p40">Friedman 2009, p. 40.</ref> While the ship carried the same armament as normal thirty-knotter destroyers, the more powerful engines needed more coal and hence more [[Fireman (steam engine)|stokers]] were needed to feed the coal to the engines, with ''Express''{{'}} crew being 73 officers and men, compared to 63 for standard Laird-built thirty-knotters.<ref name="Lyon p106">Lyon 2001, p. 106.</ref><ref name="Manning p40">Manning 1961, p. 40.</ref>
''Express'' was [[Keel laying|laid down]] on at Laird's [[Birkenhead]] shipyard on 1 December 1896 as [[Glossary of nautical terms#Yard number|Yard number]] 629, and was [[Ceremonial ship launching|launched]] on 11 December 1897.<ref name="Lyon p26"/> ''Express'' was subject to an extensive series of trials over an 18-month period in an attempt to reach the contracted speed of 33 knots. Although Lairds managed to drive the ship's machinery to up to {{convert|10012|ihp}}, well in excess of the rated {{convert|9250|ihp}}, and experimented with different propellers, ''Express'' failed to reach the required speeds. It was eventually decided by the [[Admiralty]] to accept ''Express'' despite this failure in recognition of Laird's great efforts and expense in trying to reach the over-optimistic requirement, and the fact that forcing the ship's machinery further was likely to cause excessive wear.<ref name="Lyon p29">Lyon 2001, p. 29.</ref> ''Express'' was eventually commissioned in February 1902.<ref name="Lyon p26"/>
==Service== ''Express'' served in British waters throughout her career.<ref name="Lyon p29"/> ''Express'' collided with the stores ship RFA ''Aquarius'' in December 1907 at [[Lamlash]], [[Isle of Arran]], Scotland.<ref>{{cite web|last=White|first=Christopher J.|title=RFA Aquarius|publisher=Historical RFA|url=http://www.historicalrfa.org/rfa-aquarius|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> In 1909 ''Express'' was part of the Fifth Destroyer Flotilla, based at [[HMNB Devonport|Devonport]], and was still part of that Flotilla in 1912.<ref name="nmm">{{cite web|url=http://www.rmg.co.uk/upload/pdf/Warship_Histories_Vessels_i.pdf|title=NMM, vessel ID 366548|work=Warship Histories, vol i|publisher=[[National Maritime Museum]]|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> On 30 August 1912 the Admiralty directed all destroyers were to be grouped into classes designated by letters based on contract speed and appearance. Four-funneled, 30-knotter destroyers were grouped as the [[B-class destroyer (1913)|B Class]], and ''Express'' was assigned to this class.<ref name="Conway06 p18">Gardiner and Gray 1985, p. 18.</ref><ref name="Manning p17-8">Manning 1961, pp. 17–18.</ref> In 1912, it was decided to allocate older destroyers to dedicated Patrol Flotillas, with ''Express'' being allocated to the Seventh Flotilla, based at Devonport.<ref name="Manning p25">Manning 1961, p. 25.</ref><ref name="nmm"/> On 8 May 1913, she struck the British passenger-cargo ship {{SS|Leicester|1891|2}} in the dock at [[Grimsby]] and damaged her.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Second mishap to a destroyer |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000273/19130508/117/0005 |newspaper=Yorkshire Evening Post |location=England |date=8 May 1913 |access-date=9 November 2015|via = [[British Newspaper Archive]] |subscription=yes }}</ref> ''Express'' remained part of the Seventh Flotilla until November 1913,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Fleets and Squadrons in Commission at Home and Abroad: Patrol Flotillas|journal=The Navy List|date=December 1913|page=269d|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=94336710|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> but by January 1914 had transferred to the Eighth Destroyer Flotilla, another patrol flotilla based at [[Chatham Dockyard|Chatham]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Fleets and Squadrons in Commission at Home and Abroad: Patrol Flotillas|journal=The Navy List|date=February 1914|page=269d|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=91820645&mode=fullsize|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref>
''Express'' remained part of the Eighth Flotilla at the outbreak of the [[First World War]], with the Flotilla transferring to the [[Forth Estuary]].<ref name="Manning p26">Manning 1961, p. 26.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Ships of the Royal Navy - Location/Action Date, 1914–1918: Part 2 - Admiralty "Pink Lists", 5 August 1914|publisher=Naval-history.net|url=http://www.naval-history.net/WW1NavyBritishShips-Locations2PL1408.htm|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> ''Express'', still part of the Eighth Flotilla, was undergoing a long refit in January 1917,<ref>{{cite web|title= Ships of the Royal Navy - Location/Action Date, 1914–1918: Part 2 - Admiralty "Pink Lists", 1 January 1917|publisher=Naval-history.net|url=http://www.naval-history.net/WW1NavyBritishShips-Locations2PL1701.htm|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> but in June 1917 she transferred to the East Coast Convoy Flotilla, based on the [[Humber]], which became part of the Seventh Destroyer Flotilla in July.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Naval List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officers Commands, &c. : VIII. — Local Defence Flotillas|journal=The Navy List|date=June 1917|page=17|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=92148834|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Ships of the Royal Navy - Location/Action Date, 1914–1918: Part 2 - Admiralty "Pink Lists", 30 June 1917|publisher=Naval-history.net|url=http://www.naval-history.net/WW1NavyBritishShips-Locations2PL1706.htm|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Naval List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officers Commands, &c. : VI. — Vessels Under Rear-Admiral Commanding East Coast of England: East Coast Convoy Flotilla |journal=The Navy List|date=July 1917|page=16|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=92148834|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Naval List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officers Commands, &c. : VI. — Vessels Under Rear-Admiral Commanding East Coast of England: Seventh Destroyer Flotilla: East Coast Convoys |journal=The Navy List|date=August 1917|page=16|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=94241858|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> By December that year, ''Express'' had moved to the Northern Division of the Coast of Ireland Station,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Navy List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officers' Commands, &c.: VII. — Coast of Ireland Station|journal=The Navy List|date=December 1917|page=17|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=92177542|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> based at [[Larne]] and carrying out patrols in the [[North Channel (Great Britain and Ireland)|North Channel]] between Scotland and the North of Ireland <ref>{{cite web|title=Ships of the Royal Navy - Location/Action Date, 1914–1918: Part 2 - Admiralty "Pink Lists", 2 January 1918|publisher=Naval-history.net|url=http://www.naval-history.net/WW1NavyBritishShips-Locations2PL1801.htm|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> ''Express'' remained operating on the North Channel Patrol until the end of the war.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ships of the Royal Navy - Location/Action Date, 1914–1918: Part 2 - Admiralty "Pink Lists", 11 November 1918|publisher=Naval-history.net|url=http://www.naval-history.net/WW1NavyBritishShips-Locations2PL1811.htm|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref>
''Express'' was on the Sale List in December 1919,<ref>{{cite journal|title=List of Obsolete Vessels, and Vessels for Sale|journal=The Navy List|date=January 1920|page=1105a|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=92630210|accessdate=28 March 2015}}</ref> and was sold for scrapping to G Clarkson of [[Whitby]] on 17 March 1920.<ref name="Lyon p29"/>
==Pennant numbers== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Pennant number<ref name="ditt p57">Dittmar and Colledge 1972, p. 57.</ref> ||From||To |- |D84||1914||September 1915 |- |D80||September 1915||January 1918 |- |D34||January 1918||Retirement |}

D.|title=The British Destroyer|year=1961|publisher=Putnam & Co. Ltd|location=London|oclc= 6470051}} <!-- non-breaking space to keep AWB drones from altering the space before the navbox-->
